newsitem.title: FRANCE: French shares close up 1.41 pct, Rhone jumps.
newsitem.headline: French shares close up 1.41 pct, Rhone jumps.

text.p: French shares closed sharply higher on Wednesday in big volume boosted by options expiry after it shrugged off a decline in the afternoon on stronger than expected U.S. economic growth.

The Bourse, which is closed on Thursday for the May Day holiday, started with a 1.47 percent gain, building on Tuesday's two percent advance due to a jump on Wall Street as data on labour costs and durable goods dispelled inflation fears.
But a rise in first quarter U.S. GDP, the biggest rise for more than nine years, pulled shares back to trade nearly flat in the afternoon.
Wall Street's early advances, a strong dollar and comments by U.S Commerce Under Secretary Everett Ehrlich that there was no sign of inflation, helped shartes.

The CAC-40 index closed up 1.41 percent at 2639.46, a rise of 36.60 points, but remained below the opening high of 2,641.18. April CAC-40 futures were 16.5 points higher at 2,621.5. Volume was 9.6 billion francs of which 7.4 billion was in CAC-40 stocks.
* Rhone-Poulenc was the star of the day. It closed up 4.47 percent at 196.30 francs, below an opening jump of 9.1 percent.
The company reported a 6.5 percent rise in first quarter net income -- one of the first French companies to issue their 1997 first quarter data -- which was in line with expectations.

The market was impressed by the company sticking to its forecast of a 20 percent increase in 1997 earnings per share, before exceptionals, despite the costs of a recall at its Cention unit. These costs are likely to be exceptional charges.
Paribas maintained its strong buy on Rhone-Poulenc and Cheuvreux de Virieu put Rhone on its recommended list, dropping Legrand, down 0.91 percent at 985 francs.
* Sommer-Allibert, up 0.73 percent at 1,379 francs saw more than two percent of its share capital change hands after a series of block trades in the morning.
* Online information service provider Infonie, down 27.01 percent at 100 francs, tumbled on an unexpectedly large 1996 loss and a planned capital increase.
* Pinault-Printemps,up 2.21 percent at 2,455, said its first quarter shares were 5.9 percent up.
* GAN fell 3.5 percent at 138 francs in the second day after it reported a bigger than expected 5.7 billion francs 1996 loss. The share had already lost five percent on Tuesday.
* Groupe Paribas rose 0.03 percent to close at 368.10 francs a share after several block trades involving more than three million shares were made following Tuesday's close, market sources said.
Traders said the deal could be linked to the tax credit for the 1996 dividend which goes ex-dividend on May 5.
There have also been market rumours Paribas could undergo a financial restructuring, merge with Cie Bancaire or carry out some other major transaction to finance a big overseas acquisition.
